I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) aims to support the South Asian 
Association  for  Regional  Cooperation  (SAARC)  and  its  eight  member  states  catalyze  and 
implement policies and measures to increase regional cooperation and integration (RCI) and 
reinforce the growth momentum of the region.1 
 
2.  The TA is consistent with and supportive of the Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 
7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration 2019–2024, and addresses the plan’s three 
strategic pillars: greater and higher quality connectivity between economies, expanded global and 
regional trade and investment opportunities, and increased and diversified regional public goods.2 
The TA is also aligned with the country programs as all SAARC member states have identified 
RCI as a key aspect to address national and regional development issues.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  SAARC is a regional organization comprising Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, 
Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. It was established in 1985 to improve the quality of life 
for the people of South Asia through collective actions that would accelerate social progress and 
economic growth. Since then, SAARC has made significant achievements in RCI.  
 
4.  SAARC held 18 summits, 37 sessions of the SAARC Council of Ministers (of SAARC 
foreign ministers), and 42 sessions of the Standing Committee (of SAARC foreign secretaries). 
These led to major agreements such as the Agreement on South Asian Free Trade Area and the 
SAARC Agreement on Trade in Services. These also led to a commitment to move toward a 
South  Asian  Economic  Union,  implementation  of  the  SAARC  visa  exemption  scheme, 
improvement  in  transport  connectivity,  and  progress  on  energy  trade.  SAARC  signed 
memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with 25 international organizations and 26 agreements 
and conventions for collaborative projects in various sectors. It also established some SAARC-
specialized bodies and regional centers that serve as “centers of excellence” in specific fields. 
SAARC also created technical committees and working groups focused on specific areas of 
cooperation.  
 
5.  While  SAARC  has  scored  some  successes  over  the  years,  challenges  impede  the 
realization of RCI’s full potential in the region, particularly the timely implementation of agreed 
RCI initiatives. South Asia remains one of Asia’s less-integrated subregions. The region scored 
0.435 on the Asia-Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index, which is below the average 
regional integration index score of 0.495.4  
 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the website of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on 
18 February 2020. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019–
2024. Manila. 
3  Six member states of SAARC (Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, and Sri Lanka)  are part of the South 
Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC), with the vision of boosting intraregional trade and cooperation in 
South Asia while also developing connectivity and trade with Southeast Asia. Afghanistan and Pakistan are members 
of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC), which aims to promote development through 
cooperation, leading to accelerated growth and poverty reduction. 
4  The Asia-Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index captures the contributions of six different aspects of 
regional integration: trade and investment, money and finance, regional value chains, infrastructure and connectivity, 
movement of people, and institutional and social integration.

2 
6.  Intraregional trade in 2018 accounted for about 6.3% of total trade while intraregional 
foreign direct investment was a meager 0.1% of the total foreign direct investment for SAARC 
member states. This is in stark contrast to the figures for the same period for Southeast Asia, 
recorded at 23.1% for total trade and 16.5% for intraregional foreign direct investment; East Asia,  
at 35.5% and 46.4%; and Central Asia, at 7.6% and 2.9%.5 This is in large part because of the 
high cost of intra-SAARC trade—it is more costly for SAARC countries to trade with their 
neighbors than with the European Union and the United States. The enormous potential of 
regional trade remains underexploited; gravity models show that total goods traded within the 
subregion  could  be  worth  $67  billion,  compared  to  the  actual  trade  of  $23  billion.6 This 
underscores the need to improve trade facilitation and infrastructure connectivity in the region. 
According to the Asia-Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index, South Asia scores the 
lowest in infrastructure and connectivity among all the subregions in Asia. 
  
7.  A study by United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific 
reveals that the low RCI in SAARC member states does not reflect poor complementarities among 
member states but rather the absence of appropriate compliance with the agreed reforms. 
Strengthening the implementation of RCI initiatives could help unlock South Asia’s growth 
potential. 7  Integration  can  be  improved  by  reducing  transport  costs,  improving  logistics 
infrastructure, promoting trade in the service sector, substantially reducing barriers to trade, 
pursuing monetary and financial integration, providing platforms for broader knowledge sharing, 
and enhancing collective actions on regional public goods including climate change.  
 
8.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been supporting SAARC in the following areas: 
(i) disseminating research and knowledge; (ii) building capacity and strengthening institutions; 
and (iii) facilitating regional policy dialogue.8 In 2004, ADB and the SAARC Secretariat signed an 
MOU to promote regional cooperation among the SAARC member states. Under the MOU, ADB 
and the SAARC Secretariat agreed to support member states’ efforts to attain sustainable poverty 
reduction by promoting (i) programs and activities that will accelerate broad-based economic 
growth, social development, and good governance; and (ii) cross-border movements of goods, 
services, and people through regional cooperation among the member states. They also agreed 
to promote programs and activities designed to establish institutional linkages between SAARC 
and  other  regional  cooperation  initiatives  such  as  the  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic 
Cooperation (SASEC) and the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC). 
 
9.  In November 2019, the SAARC Secretariat requested ADB’s continued financial and 
technical support to promote RCI in the region. The TA will build on the work completed and 
lessons learned from ADB’s previous and ongoing support to SAARC. These include engendering 
political commitment from SAARC member states to ensure that the studies and dialogues will

10.  SAARC  includes  resource-rich  member  states  and  some  of  the  fastest-growing 
economies in ADB’s Central and West Asia Department and South Asia Department, and 
complements other RCI programs including CAREC and SASEC, for which ADB serves as 
secretariat. The TA will explore greater synergies with ADB’s ongoing or planned operations for 
the two subregional cooperation programs and will further strengthen cooperation with SAARC to 
move forward the inter-subregional RCI agenda. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  RCI  among  SAARC  member  states 
increased.9 The TA will have the following outcome: implementation of RCI initiatives in SAARC 
enhanced.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Analytical studies on priority regional development issues produced. The 
analytical studies will produce operationally relevant knowledge and identify regional projects that 
could be included in the respective country’s development plan and ADB’s regional lending 
pipelines. Topics that will be covered include transport connectivity, trade and investment, and 
other priority regional development issues. The transport study will focus on linking South Asia 
with Central Asia by all modes of transport and will update the SAARC Regional Multimodal 
Transport Study.11 The study on trade and investment will seek to harmonize both the 8-digit tariff 
lines and customs tariffs in SAARC member states.12 Other analytical studies may also be 
conducted especially those relating to coronavirus disease pandemic and other issues that may 
be requested by the SAARC Secretariat and member states. 
 
13.  Output 2: Capacity building, knowledge sharing, and policy dialogues organized. 
The topics to be covered include: (i) climate change: ADB will review the implementation of the 
Thimphu Statement on Climate Change, develop a road map for implementing the study on 
climate risks in the SAARC region, and suggest ways forward based on the current status;13 (ii) 
poverty reduction: ADB will review the SAARC Plan of Action on Poverty Alleviation in light of the 
2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development;14 (iii) regional economic integration: ADB will review

of the SAARC finance ministers which is held on the sidelines of every ADB Annual Meeting. The 
TA team will organize some of these activities in collaboration with concerned ADB departments—

climate  change—and  in  collaboration  with  other  international  organizations  and  mutually 
recognized partners. Other topics such as regional public health system may also be included 
upon discussion with SAARC. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which (i) $300,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6: $225,000 and TASF-other sources: 
$75,000) and (ii) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Fund.16 The key expenditure items are provided in Appendix 2. A future increase in 
the TA amount is highly likely as new analytical studies and knowledge sharing opportunities are 
expected to be added given the current global health pandemic which affected various sectors of 
the economies of SAARC member states. 
 
15.  These  fund  sources  will  finance  the  TA  activities  and  outputs  including  operational 
expenses in the form of consulting services, training events, conferences, workshops, and other 
TA-related activities. The TA will not use the funds for civil works, procurement of large-scale 
equipment, or permanent staffing costs.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA  through  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Operations 
Coordination Division of the South Asia Department in close consultation with the SAARC 
Secretariat and member states, as well as ADB’s Central and West Asia Department, RCI 
Thematic  Group,  and  other  relevant  units  and  departments.  ADB  will  engage  individual 
consultants, procure goods, and organize workshops for the implementation of TA activities.

18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage individual international and national consultants 
for the implementation of activities. These consultants will be engaged individually because (i) 
they will operate in different countries, (ii) the timing of engagement will differ among countries, 
(iii) consultants will work and generate outputs independently, and (iv) consultant management 
will be performed by staff of the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division of 
the South Asia Department. ADB will consider output-based (lump-sum) contracts for consulting 
services, as appropriate. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.17  
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening the Implementation of Regional Cooperation and Integration Initiatives of the South 
Asian Association for Regional Cooperation, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
